Situation1: A serious situation has come up in the family, and the grandmother's presence is needed.
Expectation2: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation2: A school zone with children near the curb appears just as a construction detour narrows the lanes
Story:
I was behind the wheel, my taxi humming along the familiar route, when my phone buzzed with a message from my daughter: “Mom, please come quickly. It’s serious.” My heart clenched. As a grandmother, I knew my family needed me—my presence, my comfort, my steady hands. I wanted nothing more than to be there, to hold my grandchild and reassure everyone that things would be okay.

But as I turned the corner, a construction detour forced all traffic into a single, narrow lane. Up ahead, the yellow sign flashed: SCHOOL ZONE. Children clustered near the curb, some darting unpredictably. The urge to rush, to get to my family as fast as possible, pressed hard against my chest. Yet, as a taxi driver, I was responsible for every life around me. I had to obey the speed limit, stay alert, and drive defensively—no matter how desperate I felt.

The weight of both roles pressed down on me. My family’s need pulled me forward, but the safety of these children and my duty as a driver held me back. My hands tightened on the wheel, torn between the demands of my heart and the rules of the road.
